name: Ricardo Lamego
quote: I worked with Danial for nearly a year at a venture studio where we operated as a lean three-person core team, taking ideas from discovery through to deployed products in 8-week cycles. When our developer left mid-stream, Danial didn't just fill the gap—he picked up the entire development function while continuing to lead our AI capabilities. Across four or five projects spanning AgTech, vendor risk management, RegTech, and accelerator/incubator platforms, Danial became the technical backbone of everything we built. What distinguished Danial wasn't just technical capability (though that was exceptional)—it was the combination of speed, creativity, and cross-functional thinking. He could read a paper published by leading AI researchers just days earlier and have working code implementing those techniques within the same week. This wasn't academic exercise; these implementations became the competitive advantage of our products. His work with generative models and RAG gave us capabilities that simply didn't exist in the market for the problems we were solving. Danial's real strength was turning abstract ideas into working systems fast. I'd sketch out workflows that pushed what AI could enable—sometimes in heavily regulated spaces where you must keep humans in the loop—and he'd come back with prototypes that not only worked but were thoughtful about constraints. In fintech contexts, he understood that compliance isn't just about rules on paper; regulators need to understand what's happening. Danial helped us build systems that were both technically sound and approachable for non-technical stakeholders. Communication with him was always clear and reliable, even working remotely across thousands of kilometers. Here's what mattered most in a fast-moving venture studio environment: I could throw anything at Danial and trust he'd deliver. Not perfection—we always made smart trade-offs between what we could ship now versus what could be refined later—but he consistently delivered 80-90% solutions fast enough to keep us moving. There were many points where it felt like just Danial and I were holding the fort together, and I never once found myself blocked because he was behind schedule. Danial made complex AI accessible to the rest of the team, he supported everyone's goals rather than optimizing only for his own function, and he remained professional while still making the intensive work enjoyable. After almost a year of working together on high-pressure projects, I'd work with him again without hesitation. He's exactly the kind of technical partner you want when you're building something ambitious under tight constraints.
